audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker introducing the purpose of the video, which is to explain how to disable the DHCP service from AT&T and allow a home router to take control of a home network. His tone is conversational. There is a pause before the speaker suggests to "get on with it,".

The clip begins with a male speaker advising on accessing an AT&T U-verse router. He explains how to find the IP number and the importance of the administrative password if connecting wirelessly. His tone is informative. He notes that a network cable connection wouldn't require the password. Finally, the clip ends abruptly.

The clip starts with a male speaker explaining that with an IP number at hand, one can open a browser, type the number, press enter, and be taken to an administrative page. He specifies that because he's connected to his AT&T U-verse modem via network cable, he's not prompted for a password. His tone is informative and straightforward.

The audio begins with a male speaker offering a warning about backing up information on routers before making changes. He explains that if changes don't work, it's possible to revert to a previous state, emphasizing that the listener is now warned.

The clip begins with a male speaker explaining how to click on "settings" and navigate to "LAN", then "DHCP". He describes selecting the option to configure manually and typing in the IP address of the AT&T U-verse router, as well as the subnet mask. He elaborates on restricting the range of IP addresses used by the DHCP server to a single IP address, that of the home router, advising to set both the first and last IP addresses of the range to the same number. Finally, he instructs to save and move to the firewall, all delivered in a calm, instructive tone.

The clip features one male speaker providing instructions, advising the listener to navigate through applications, pinholes, and DMZ. He outlines the process of typing in an IP address for a home router and then saving the changes. He then guides the listener to the LAN tab and the WiFi sub-tab, where he directs the listener to disable both the 2.4 GHz and 5 GHz WiFi networks. His instructions are followed by a declaration that "that's it."

The audio clip features one male speaker providing instructions, starting with phrases like "after configuring" and "you will need to unplug it." He then describes specific steps involving removing a power cable and configuring a home router, while mentioning details about an ASUS router, firmware version, and an IP address. A brief pause is followed by more instructions involving typing a number and logging in to an administrative interface.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker outlining the initial steps for configuring a setting, stating they need to go to the "WAN tab" and transform it from automatic to static IP. He explains he will input the IP address configured on the AT&T router, providing the IP address number. He then moves on to the default gateway and DNS server settings. Next, he clicks the "apply" button. Then, he moves on to the LAN option.

The clip starts with a male speaker discussing configuring a home router. He specifically mentions using the IP address "192.168.2.1," emphasizing the importance of the third number in the sequence, which he says should not be "one" to avoid conflicts with the AT&T U-Verse router. He then advises the listener to use other numbers up to 255, before mentioning that you should apply and save the changes. He concludes by stating that the network should work properly after those configurations. Throughout the speech, the speaker has an informative tone. Intermittently, there is generic instrumental music playing in the background.

The audio clip begins with one male speaker wishing someone good luck with a router change and expressing hope for a successful configuration. This is followed by music that sounds like a slow, mellow electronic piece. The main instruments seem to be synthesizers creating a melancholic mood. Following that is a distinct buzzing sound.
